texts.shortText: Unusual octocoral with a flattened, ribbon-like, creeping stolon that adheres to the surfaces of rocks and branches irregularly, periodically giving rise to isolated (or small groups of) polyps. Polyps borne on short, slightly-opaque, cylindrical stalks, into which they can contract. Stolon yellowish and contains knobbly sclerites, which are clearly visible through the surface, but these are absent from polyps, which are clear and transparent.  Polyps each with 8 tentacles that are lined by small side-branches.
Colonies reaching at least 50 mm in length, individual polyps 2-4 mm tall.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Known only from Cape Peninsula.

A recently described species, but quite common in its specialized habitat. Usually found on the underside of boulders. Nothing else is known about the biology of this species, which is currently documented only from a few records.
Presumed to be predatory on small invertebrates that are stung by the nematocysts on the tentacles and transferred to the mouth.

No details on this species, but generally in this group colonies expand asexually by budding new polyps. Sexual reproduction can involve mass spawning of sperm and eggs into the water or brooding, where sperm is released and fertilized eggs are retained and brooded by female polyps until larvae are fully formed, after which these are released.
Several other octocorals occur in similar habitats, but the creeping habits and pale colour of this species are unusual and make it fairly easy to identify.

McFadden, S & van Ofwegen, LP (2012). Stoloniferous octocorals (Anthozoa, Octocorallia) from South Africa, with descriptions of a new family of Alcyonacea, a new genus of Clavulariidae, and a new species of Cornularia (Cornulariidae). Invertebrate Systematics. 26: 331-356.
